qas.question: Who is the only person who can judge a Cardinal in regards to laws of the church?

plausible_answers.text: exemption from being judged by ecclesiastical tribunals of ordinary rank

qas.question: What does the privilege of democracy guarantee cardinals and popes?
Who is forbidden to judge cardinals in matters subject to ecclesiastical jurisdiction?
What does the pope either decide or delegates the decision to the the College of Cardinals?

plausible_answers.text: to the civil and criminal law

qas.question: What are cardinals not subject to like everybody else?

context: Cardinals have in canon law a "privilege of forum" (i.e., <b1_0>exemption from being judged by ecclesiastical tribunals of ordinary rank<b1_0/>): only <a0_0><b2_0>the pope<b2_0/><a0_0/> is competent to judge them in matters subject to ecclesiastical jurisdiction (cases that refer to matters that are spiritual or linked with the spiritual, or with regard to infringement of ecclesiastical laws and whatever contains an element of sin, where culpability must be determined and the appropriate ecclesiastical penalty imposed). The pope either decides <b3_0>the case<b3_0/> himself or delegates the decision to a tribunal, usually one of the tribunals or congregations of the Roman Curia. Without such delegation, no ecclesiastical court, even the Roman Rota, is competent to judge a canon law case against a cardinal. Cardinals are, however, subject <b4_0>to the civil and criminal law<b4_0/> like everybody else.
